awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Impairment, Resilience, and Social Networks Among Disabled Women
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists of disability have long noted that with age, everyone eventually becomes disabled. As medical technologies improve, innovative treatments for numerous impairments increase the number of disabled Americans. Amid this accelerated growth, there is an increased need to understand what factors enhance or limit the accommodations and resources that are made to disabled individuals. This doctoral research project investigates the everyday experiences and social networks of a population of disabled women in the U.S. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, findings will be shared with governmental and non-governmental organizations, doctors, and others with the aim of improving the care of disabled individuals. The project also endeavors to enhance the public's understanding of science and the scientific method with regard to disabled Americans. 

This doctoral dissertation research project examines the relationship between experiences of disability and gender, and what support networks improve or worsen these experiences.  The project explores the experiences of individuals with Turner Syndrome (TS), a chromosome and hormone disorder that impacts one in every 2,000 live female births. TS frequently causes delayed or incomplete maturation and infertility, making it a unique case study for examining the relationship between gender and disability. Research will be conducted in North Carolina, an ideal locale given the clustering of individuals with this disorder: a number of nonprofits and a dedicated TS clinic offer access to this population and their resources. Interviews, observation of daily activities, along with experimental methods in collaborative ethnography will afford insight into the everyday experiences of individuals with TS, including what struggles they face, what resilience they demonstrate, and what resources they rely on and need.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This dissertation research has investigated the experiences of individuals with Turner Syndrome (TS), a sex chromosome and hormone disorder that impacts one in every 2,000 live female births. Through a combination of in-person and virtual interviews, observation at nonprofit events, and theatrical explorations including playwriting and performance with participants, this research explored how gender identity impacts experiences of disability and the role of support networks in shaping everyday struggles and moments of resilience.

Individuals with TS typically experience infertility as the result of a partially or entirely missing X chromosome. Results from this study suggest that those with the condition contribute to their own forms of reproduction through intergenerational interactions and the passing down of knowledge about and activism for those with the condition. In turn, those with TS challenge our assumptions of who can reproduce and through what means. This theory may be useful for researchers interested in the reproductive experiences of other sex and gender minorities, helping to inform policies around reproductive laws and policy-making.

Similarly, this research found that those with TS often occupy shifting, ambiguous spaces between female and not female and disabled and not disabled. Participants simultaneously recognized their identities as distinct from a medically and socially informed “norm” while distinguishing themselves from those they imagined to more severely deviate, including individuals with intellectual disabilities and trans individuals. This research suggests that it is precisely because those with TS occupy this uniquely gendered disability identity that they demonstrate how we all differentially identify with and against norms to construct our concepts of self and meaning, especially when faced with rupturing experiences including diagnosis and illness. Understanding these common but often obfuscated processes can improve our awareness of the social creation and impact of disabilities, especially for sex and gender minorities. In turn, results from this research may reduce stigma and increase awareness of disability experience.

This research discovered that care serves a critical means through which those with TS come to make sense of their experiences with the condition. Care operates both on the level of self-care as one works through complex, personal experiences and on the level of caring for others, through which everyday means of activism can enhance self-understandings of the condition. A five-month rehearsal process with six participants fostered a collaborative setting built on shared vulnerability and improvisation through which participants made sense of these complex experiences. The process enabled the researcher to demonstrate care for participants by improving the accessibility of rehearsals to meet the mental, emotional, and bodily needs of those who participated. This research therefore suggests a move toward a care-oriented anthropology that prioritizes accessibility, recognizes everyday acts of creativity as integral to the meaning-making process, and embraces moments of uncertainty as opportunities for improving research practices to better understand the experiences of those whom we study.

Over the course of 24 months, this research produced a video of four monologues through which participants shared their experiences of TS. It similarly produced two virtual performances of original plays to educate the public on TS, one with two participants and another with six. During the rehearsal process, participants reported therapeutic benefits as they shared their stories with others in the TS community, improving their understandings of themselves and one another as they contributed to the initial analysis of key themes in the research. These theatrical endeavors demonstrated the indirect therapeutic benefits of collaborative, creative methods and the utility of these approaches not only for scientific knowledge production but also for creating and disseminating research products that are accessible and effectively engage public audiences. Collectively, hundreds of people have viewed two livestreamed performances and three publicly shared videos of the original plays co-written by the researcher and participants, demonstrating the ability of these media to contribute public awareness of a common disability that reveals larger inequalities for disability and gender minorities in the United States.

This research further contributed a presentation on accessibility for the Society of Psychological Anthropology, which was co-presented by the researcher and a research participant. The researcher has a forthcoming article in the psychological anthropology journal Ethos and will be presenting at the American Anthropological Association conference. The research therefore provided important opportunities for those with TS to directly contribute to scientific knowledge and has already been recognized by prominent anthropological organizations. Throughout the research, the researcher worked closely with TS nonprofits and a TS clinic to organize and share the original performances of plays on TS experiences. The researcher will continue to share written and visual products from this research with the international, national, and local TS community via the nonprofits TSGA, TSF, TSS, and TSC as well as with doctors and researchers interested in improving holistic care for other sex chromosome and hormone disorders, disabilities, and under-researched or otherwise invisible conditions.
